Comment: The thing is tho, as a black man, myself, I've never heard anyone I know talk about retribution or anything like that. We're not interested in wielding majority status (if we ever had it) as a weapon against anyone else. We, I, want to mind my business and be left alone.   The problem is kinda simple.   These people know the minority groups suffer for the choices made by the majority group... they can't imagine a scenario where that's not true. On the one hand, it's a tacit acknowledgement of the bullshit they know they're going. But they are also thinking of what they would do, if they were in our shoes. And they're too self-centered to even see that. So when you tell them this, instead of it dawning on them like "damn, I am projecting and that's not cool," they start talking crazy about any and everything but the issue as a type of self protection from cognitive dissonance.

Comment: I know. And honestly—looking back at my shitty childhood, deprived of basic needs, hiding in cold shelters and later in refugee camps for years—reading this is deeply offensive. To me, and to every person like me who still, decades later, has PTSD from all the horrors we've seen. We were personae non gratae. No country would take us. Very little was done to help. Our food was Ikar cans and cookies from the Vietnam War. (I'm not joking.) And then I read this. What the hell has happened to this world?  Sorry for the emotional rant.
